Here is some important information regarding new Pandemic EBT benefits for free and reduced price eligible families.

Because schools are closed due to COVID-19, families eligible for free and reduced price school meals may be eligible to receive up to $365 per child to help buy food for their family. This is in addition to any emergency meals they may be getting at school. These food benefits are called Pandemic EBT or P-EBT.

Most families who receive CalFresh, CalWORKS, Medi-Cal or other social services benefits will automatically get a P-EBT card in the mail before May 22. The P-EBT card can be used like a debit card to buy food and groceries for children. Please keep an eye out for this card in the mail over the next few weeks.

If your family qualifies for free or reduced price meals but does not receive a P-EBT card in the mail by May 22, you will need to complete a simple and quick online application at ca.p-ebt.org. This web portal opens May 22 and applications must be received before June 30, 2020. For more information, visit ca.p-ebt.org/info.

The Alta Loma School District celebrated the completion of the newly constructed 11,500-square-foot classroom building at Deer Canyon Elementary School with a ribbon-cutting ceremony Friday.

Senator Mike Morrell, Rancho Cucamonga Mayor Pro-Tem Lynne Kennedy, City Council Member Sam Spagnolo and the entire Alta Loma School District Board of Trustees were on hand for the event. ALSD Superintendent James Moore and Deer Canyon Principal Donna Carlson welcomed students, staff and the community to the ceremony and to view the state-of-the-art facility, which will serve the community for generations to come.

Senator Mike Morrell, Rancho Cucamonga Mayor Pro-Tem Lynne Kennedy, City Council Member Sam Spagnolo and the entire Alta Loma School District Board of Trustees were on hand for the event. ALSD Superintendent James Moore and Deer Canyon Principal Donna Carlson welcomed students, staff and the community to the ceremony and to view the state-of-the-art facility, which will serve the community for generations to come.

post_text: Vineyard Junior High School and the city of Rancho Cucamonga participated in National Walk and Bike to School Day Wednesday. The nationwide event presented by the National Center for Safe Routes to School is part of the effort to create safe conditions for walkable neighborhoods. Vineyard students met at Hermosa Elementary and Hermosa Park and walked with school teachers and administrators. They were joined by Rancho Cucamonga Mayor Pro-Tem Lynne Kennedy, council members Kristine Scott and Ryan Hutchison, and City Manager John Gillson. The walk concluded with an assembly at the school, where city officials presented Principal Sandy Rose with a proclamation recognizing Vineyard's efforts to promote safe routes to school. Several lucky students who participated in the event came away with raffle prizes, including a new bicycle. The Alta Loma School District officially broke ground Friday on a new 11,500-square-foot classroom building at that is scheduled to open in fall 2019 at Deer Canyon Elementary School. Ceremonies featured all five members of the ALSD Board of Trustees -- Brad Buller, Sandy Oerly, Rebecca Davies, Caryn Payzant and Dave Roberts -- along with Rancho Cucamonga Mayor Dennis Michael, Mayor Pro Tem Lynne Kennedy, Assembly Member Marc Steinorth and the staff and students from Deer Canyon Elementary.

When complete, the new permanent building will have eight classrooms, offices, workrooms and more -- all equipped with the latest technology to serve ALSD students for generations to come.

The project is being financed through the Measure H general obligation bond fund approved by Alta Loma voters in November 2016. This is the first major construction project funded by the Measure H bond.
